name: Support the Cause!  Google I/O Extended is coming to NJ.  Help us get ready!

venue.name: Montclair State University (University Hall, Classroom on 2nd Floor)

description:
This is a call to arms for all of our techies out there to help GDG North Jersey prepare to host Google I/O Extended for the whole state of New Jersey! In particular, we need help conducting some of the following activities:

1) Code Labs 

This is basically a presentation where you deliver a walkthrough of a technology that you're very familiar with, and can speak about / live code for a segment of time. We can even pair you with someone else and divide and conquer individual pieces of related technologies. Google has done a really good job of feeding me some fantastic content for this program, including things like "Polymer", which I'm going to say has a chance of revolutionizing web development.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3pYGVB2lG9w

I can provide you with plenty of other jaw dropping techs to demo :). 

2) Code Reviews 

This is a collaborative mentoring session where we will collect a bunch of talented developers, architects and other technologists to provide assistance to anyone who's stuck on a particular project and wants some help. 

3) Google tech demos 

This is fun. I'll give you some really good content courtesy of the GDG network, and you will get to demo it. For one, we will run an entire "Android Wear" event. There are nice slide decks provided by Google, you'll simply need to gain some familiarity with them, and run through it. One great thing is that we've also been given clearance to give away 2-3 Android Wear devices for free. Pretty cool especially considering it hasn't hit the market yet. 

4) Google tech trivia 

I was kinda thinking of handling this one myself, but I think that's ambitious. I'm sure I'll need tons of help on it. Pretty self explanatory, and fun. 

Anyway, I'd love to meet everyone who I haven't previously met, and would like to get many of you involved in a really fun project that could change the landscape of tech in the Garden State! Text me directly if you have any issues finding the classroom:
[masked]

Todd

name: Google your life: Wearable demo + The top startup hacks to help your business
description:
What to expect with registration:  Food, beverages, a chance to win one of a number of Google-centric prizes, and access to all of the sessions.

Join us for a tech & entrepreneur extravaganza hosted by a consortium of local groups. Leaders and members of NJIT, GDG North Jersey, Scarlet Startups, Brick City Tech, Code for Newark and GalleryRetail will be presenting and in attendance on the campus of NJIT. We'll kick things off as a whole group in Weston Hall with some food and drinks, followed by quick overviews of the following topics: 

1) Wearable technology (Google Glass, Android Wear, Fitbits, etc.) and career tips for developers.
2) How serial entrepreneurs use technology most effectively in their everyday lives.
3) The ever-emerging entrepreneurial scene in Newark. Can Market become the next N3RD Street?? Zay, owner of GalleryRetail and Brigade Captain of Code for Newark will explain this statement.

Agenda

6:30 - 7:00  Food and networking in the Weston Hall atrium. Also make sure to get a raffle ticket. 

7:00 - 7:30  Opening statements (Todd, Clark, Anthony & Zay)

7:30 - 8:30  Breakout sessions in the two rooms off of the atrium

8:45 - 9:00  Quick closing remark and prize giveaways

The breakout sessions will consist of 2 tracks, one optimized for entrepreneurs and business people, and another aimed at developers:

Developers + Techies

A handful of GDG Jedi (Todd Nakamura, Jugal Shah and Katy Kasmai) will take a dive into Wearable technology, along the way showing you some of the nuts and bolts of developing Android Wear and Google Glass enabled apps.  We'll be building an app or two prior to the event, and we'll show you how the different features are enabled and controlled through live code demos. 

Entrepreneurs & Other Business Folk
Clark Lagemann of Scarlet Startups (and many other ventures) and Anthony Frasier of Brick City Tech (and also many other ventures) will be showing you some of their favorite time-saving, efficiency-increasing, blood-pressure-lowering tech tips and tricks that everyone should be using in their personal and professional lives. 

There are a few other surprises planned as well. It should be a fun event, and we hope you come join us and keep the community moving forward!

Speaker Profiles

Clark Lagemann: Founder of Scarlet Startups; Health Options Worldwide and MedPro Wellness 

Anthony Frasier: CoFounder at the Phat Startup; Founder, Brick City Tech

Katy Kasmai, MBA: Cofounder CEO at Xocracy; Founder, UbiTech NYC; Google Glass expert 

Todd Nakamura: Founder, GDG North Jersey and Nakamura Productions LLC; Mentor, TechLaunch

Jugal Shah: Technologist at Verizon;  GDG North Jersey Co-organizer; Android Wear developer

Isaiah Little: Founder, GalleryRetail; Brigade Captain, Code for Newark

name: Voice Control Hackathon at Lam Cloud sponsored by What Are Minds For, Inc.
description:
IMPORTANT:  Get your free ticket at Eventbrite (https://www.eventbrite.com/e/voice-control-hackathon-01-tickets-12761258267?discount=vognition&aff=gdgmeetup)

This is the 1st “Voice Control Hackathon” sponsored by What Are Minds For, Inc (WRM4).  At this weekend event, you will be provided an introduction, education and code for how to use the Vognition natural language voice control API by the founder of WRM4.  

The Voice Control Hackathon is Sept 20th and 21st at Lam Cloud (exit 8a on the turnpike).  This is a free event that includes breakfast and lunch.

Participants receive (1) an in-depth education on voice recognition, (2) freemium Vognition™ service for attending, (3) can win other prizes and (4) a voice recognition certificate.

It is expected that you are a mobile app developer. 

Itinerary:

Sept 20th: 9 AM - 6 PM

Registration and Breakfast: 9 AM

Introductions: 9:30 AM

Voice Recognition Controls Education: 10 AM

Lunch: 11:45 AM

Practice Voice Control Integration (Sample Code): 1 PM

Voice Controls Integration: 3:45 PM

Done for the Day: 6 PM

Sept 21st: 10 AM - 5 PM

Breakfast: 10 AM

Developer Boot Camp: 10:30 AM

Lunch: 12:15

Developer Boot Camp: 1 PM

Prize, Awards and a Certificate: 4:30 PM

Done for the Day: 5 PM

During this event you will be learning the inner workings of a voice recognition stack:

1. The IoT Speech Recognition Topology Landscape (ISRL)

2. How speech recognition works.

3. Old School Natural Language Processing (NLP) vs. the buzz name of NLP.

4. How true Natural Language Understanding (NLU) works vs. the data dictionary's.

5. Show how to code voice control applications. 

You will receive the following materials for attending the event:

1. Registration Packet

2. Voice control code snapshot for an iOS and Android app accessing the Vognition™ solution. Vognition™ is a natural language voice control platform.

3. A natural language voice control certificate. And a chance to win other prizes.

name: Android Wear DevFest at Drew University w/ Lisa Wray & Martin Omander of Google
description:
For everyone attending, the Hall of Sciences is within the blue circle in this diagram.  That's where the event is.  The green circle, and yellow circle and oval are also both 100% safe parking that won't get you a ticket.  I recommend the yellow circle, unless you enjoy long walks (the campus is quite nice I have to admit). 

* Make sure to bring along your laptops, and have Android Studio installed in advance if you'd like to participate in the Code Lab. 

We're thrilled to be visited by our distinguished guests from Google: Lisa Wray, Android Wear Developer Advocate and Martin Omander, Program Manager (which makes him the fearless leader of the GDG North America movement).   

Lisa Wray from Google NYC, Android Wear Developer Advocate Extraordinaire (https://plus.google.com/u/0/+LisaWrayZeitouni):

Martin Omander, the man, the myth, the legend, all the way from the Google HQ in Silicon Valley (https://plus.google.com/u/0/+MartinOmander):

We're also fortunate enough to be joined by Nitya Narasimhan, Android expert, SUNY professor and organizer of GDG Hudson Valley (https://plus.google.com/u/0/+NityaNarasimhan):

Barry Burd, not to be confused with NBA hall of famer Larry Bird, professor of computer science at Drew University and speaker at DroidCon 2014 in NYC is our gracious host:

Our guests will take us on an all-day tour through Android Wear design and development, ranging from basic to advanced topics.  Whether you're a beginner, advanced or non-developer looking to break into the field, you should be able to find something of value to add to your arsenal.  Your free registration will include coffee, snacks and lunch.  Keep in mind that free food always tastes better.  

Agenda

8:45 am:   Registration & Coffee

9:30 am:   Martin, Todd & GDG Women North Jersey Intro

10:00 am:   "Intro to Android Wear" (Lisa)

10:45 am:   Coffee Break 

11:15 am:  "Android Wear Design Sprint" (Lisa & Martin) - This is a rapid prototyping exercise that helps you understand the design principles behind Android Wear.  This will be a very interactive session that encourages full participation from attendees, and will result in you formulating a concept for a Wear app.  More info about design sprints from a great Google I/O session here. 

1:15 pm:   Lunch  + Frisbee Toss

Android Pros (Option 1)

2:15 pm:   Android Wear Code Lab (Lisa) - Lisa will lead the group through a live coding session stressing the fundamentals of development for wearables.  Make sure to bring your laptop so you can follow along.

Android Newbies (Option 2)

2:15 pm:  Intro to Android (Concepts to Code) / GDG Women TechMakers

3:45 pm:   Coffee Break + Prep your concept pitch

4:15 pm:  "Ready to Wear" -- pitch your Wear ideas to a panel of tech experts and entrepreneurs who will help to advance the concept.

Our distinguished advisors who will provide feedback and insight on your design concepts: 

Dennis Bone 

www.linkedin.com/pub/dennis-bone/11/526/a0: 

President of Verizon, NJ from 2000 - 2012 and currently Director of the Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship at Montclair State University

Mario Casabona 

www.linkedin.com/pub/mario-casabona/28/995/322

Founder and CEO at TechLaunch LLC & Casabona Ventures LLC.   Active angel investor in NJ.

Glenn Martin 

www.linkedin.com/pub/glenn-martin/4/545/5b6:

Senior Developer at ZitterHealth Insights and presenter (Polymer) at Google I/O Extended NJ 2014

Balaji Jayaraman 

https://www.linkedin.com/in/balausa:

CTO at Switch2Health (acquired by Fitbit in 2013), Founder and Technology Partner at The Atlas Project

5:30 pm:   Final words, Raffle winner & Wrap-up 

This event should be a great learning experience for anyone interested in Android Wear development.  Come out and learn from the pros.  It's not that often that we convince real New York and Silicon Valley Googlers to fly across the country or cross the Hudson, so be sure to catch this opportunity.   

* Also check out the dedicated website that just launched for more info about the event: http://devfest.gdgnorthjersey.com/wear2014

name: Cognitive Computing Tech Talk w/ IBM Watson Core Engineer & Google Researcher

venue.name: Montclair State University
venue.address_1: 1 Normal Avenue (University Hall - Conference Center 7th Floor)

description:
Here are a couple of campus maps for those who haven't been to MSU before: 

http://www.montclair.edu/campus-map/

Chris Welty is a research scientist at Google Research in NY, and a Professor of Cognitive Computing at the VU University, Amsterdam.  He was previously a member of the leadership team for Watson and IBM's Jeopardy! Challenge, at the IBM T.J. Watson Research Center in New York.  

Dr. Welty's principal area of research is the role of semantic technology in deep analytic problems such as natural language processing.  He led three technical teams in IBM's Watson project: structured knowledge exploitation, rapid domain adaptation, and crowd sourcing. 

In addition to numerous scientific achievements, Dr. Welty has played an active role in transferring research into practice through web standards, open software development, and the meetup community.

At WWW 2011, soon after the notable performance of IBM's Watson on Jeopardy,  Dr. Welty laid out the skeleton of a new computing paradigm, which IBM has since been dubbed "Cognitive Computing".  Over the three years since then, cognitive computing is proving to be a radical shift in software and information technology that disrupts previously understood terms like "performance", "feature", "debugging", and even "truth".  

In this talk, Dr. Welty will give a personal perspective on how cognitive computing has progressed and is re-shaping the software solution business and ecosystem, as well as our very expectations of what computers are capable of.

See Chris and the rest of the team at IBM talking about Watson in a behind- the-scenes video from IBM in 2011 documenting Watson's performance on Jeopardy against grand champions Ken Jennings and Brad Rutter. 

We're also extremely excited to be joined by Todd Carter, Founder/ CEO of Tagasauris Inc.

Tagasauris is an intelligent data platform for visual media that combines human assisted computing with semantic Web technologies to create networked, relationship-aware image and video objects. Todd is recognized as an innovator and entrepreneur in the digital media and linked data communities with over 20 years working experience in publishing, broadcasting and cultural heritage. 

Tagasauris has been featured in The New York Times, Wired, Business Week, The Economist and others. Tagasauris and the Museum of the City of New York are the recipients of an award from The National Endowment for the Humanities to annotate the museum's collections. 

In 2010, on the heels of a successful collaboration with the legendary photography cooperative, Magnum Photos, I began thinking anew about the possibility of teaching computers to do things with media on the Web. 

Todd believes that visual content is the currency of tomorrow's Web, that the shift from hypertext to hypermedia is both inevitable and exciting and, that once computers can understand visual media, a new generation of applications for discovery and visual-first learning will be enabled. Tagasauris' computational approach allows them to backfill the so called "semantic gap" with a layer of structured, contextual, relationship-aware data. 

This data is persisted in a knowledge base we call mediaGraph. mediaGraph has the potential to interlink the currently impoverished, disparate and silo'd descriptions of media across the Web and we believe it can power a new breed of knowledge-centric applications in the world of ubiquitous online multimedia. Tech entrepreneurs and venture capitalists focused on the Web of Data and the Visual Web might enjoy this talk. 

* Please note that Todd also has a particularly fantastic name.
how_to_find_us: Make sure to park at Red Hawk Deck and then walk to the top of the hill to University Hall (it's the tall building beyond the sports field at the top of the hill).

name: Current Trends in Big Data Analytics

venue.name: Montclair State University
venue.address_1: 1 Normal Avenue (University Hall - Conference Center 7th Floor)

description:
This event hosted by the recently formed NJ Big Data Alliance is free, but registration is necessary. 

Please register here. 

In July 2013, McKinsey identified big data as one of the game changers that will drive U.S. growth and renewal. Today, big data is transforming society and creating a huge demand for professionals with strong analytical skills, as has been documented by both MIT’s Sloan Management Review and Accenture.
This event will feature four industry executives who will share their big data analytics success stories and discuss the skills and competencies today’s employers value most.

Event is presented by the Information & Operations Management Department, School of Business, Montclair State University.

Click for directions and parking info

Presenters:
• Steve LoSardo, senior principal at IMS Health
• Joe Caserta, founder and CEO of Caserta Concepts
• Pranay Agrawal, co-founder and EVP, Fractal Analytics
• Melanie Murphy, senior director of Customer & Business Analytics, Bed, Bath & Beyond

Agenda
5:30 – 6pm: Welcome, Registration and Hors d'oeuvres
6:00pm – 8pm: Presentations and Q&A
8pm – 9pm: Networking Happy Hour

About the presenters:
Pranay Agrawal is a co-founder and member of the leadership team at Fractal Analytics. Pranay has led Fractal to a leading analytics firm with 700 analytics professionals and data scientists serving over 50 Fortune 500 companies across financial services, insurance, consumer products, retail, technology, telecom and healthcare. Fractal has helped its clients institutionalize analytics and accelerate the move towards becoming a data-based decision-making culture.

Joe Caserta is a recognized big data strategy consultant, author and educator. He is the president of Caserta Concepts, an award-winning New York-based innovation technology and consulting firm founded in 2001. Specializing in big data analytics, data warehousing and business intelligence, Caserta Concepts collaborates with CIOs and their IT organizations to gain new business insights through a better understanding of their data.

Steve LoSardo has more than 24 years of experience providing consulting and information technology services to pharma, biotech, government and other healthcare organizations. His focus at IMS Health is on data management, business intelligence, healthcare informatics, big data and real-world-evidence solutions for sales, marketing, clinical and health outcomes research professionals. Prior to IMS, Steve was with PricewaterhouseCoopers, helping pharma, payers and providers address the changes occurring in healthcare.

Melanie Murphy is senior director of Customer & Business Analytics for Bed Bath & Beyond, where she leads Quantitative Analytics, Customer & Marketing Analytics as well as the Program Management Office. Prior to joining Bed Bath & Beyond, Melanie led analytic teams for Mindtree and Experian Marketing Services. She started her career as a statistician, constructing and supervising the construction of models for companies across all industry groups. She holds a master’s degree in statistics and a bachelor’s degree in applied mathematics from Montclair State University where she received the Outstanding Masters Award in Statistics.

If you have questions, contact:
[masked]
The School of Business at Montclair State University
[masked]

name: Google Cloud Platform Extravaganza: Intro, Kubernetes (Containers) & App Engine

venue.name: Montclair State University (University Hall - Room UN1070)

description:
We're thrilled to be joined by 2 members of the Google Cloud team: one from Google NYC and one from "across the pond" at Google London.  We'll also be joined by a certain CEO of a local startup that built it's infrastructure on Google App Engine.

FEATURED TALK: A Developers guide to Google Cloud Platform 

SPEAKER: Ray Tsang, Google Developer Advocate (Cloud Team at Google NYC)

In this talk we'll introduce Google Cloud Platform and look at how Developers can get quickly up and running with Cloud development. We'll then focus specifically on solving the problem of providing cloud based storage services for mobile applications. Using code examples and demos, we will show how the Firebase Application Platform allows mobile developers to store and share data from mobile devices in real time without them having to write a single line of server side code. 

FEATURED TALK: From Docker To Kubernetes: A Developer's Guide To Containers

SPEAKER: Mandy Waite, Google Developer Advocate (Cloud Team at Google London)

Everyone is talking about Containers, but mostly in the context of how they work and not why and when they are useful or how to apply them to your own often complex and unique Use Cases. We'll look at how Google Cloud Platform enables developers when it comes to building Cloud Native applications and we'll show how support for containers fits into the big picture and provide insight into the when, why and how of using them. We'll wrap up with a cool demo of the Kubernetes Container Scheduler. 

SHORT TALK: How Spudder Uses Google App Engine

SPEAKER: Dennis Harabin is CEO of Spudder LLC  

Dennis will lead us into an exploration of Google App Engine, and specifically how his company makes use of the infrastructure to quickly build a robust web platform.
how_to_find_us: We'll be on the first floor at University Hall, in large lecture hall UN1070.

name: Solve for X: Montclair State University

venue.name: Montclair State University (University Hall - Room UN1070)

description:
A few updates about the event:

1) Agenda

We haven't finalized all of the pioneers who are presenting moonshots, but this agenda will give a sample of some of the concepts you'll be witnessing at the event: 

5:45 - 6:30: Food, networking, What's your [x]? + What's your moonshot?

6:30 - 6:45: Welcome / Opening Remarks

6:45+: Moonshot pioneer pitches along with feedback from an esteemed panel.  Let the Solve for X: New Jersey games begin! 

After Party?

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Moonshot Pioneers

Lou Elwell (SumaGrow):  It's a fertilizer alternative that uses a cocktail of microbes to return nitrogen to the soil.    

Seth Wainer & Michael Ehrlich (Smart City Newark): "Smart City Newark would be the first attempt to transform an existing US city into a fully instrumented, vendor agnostic test-bed for the insertion of IT into every imaginable aspect of urban life."

Richard G. Morris (PharmaSeq, Inc): PharmaSeq has defined a new method to perform DNA synthesis at economies of scale that are currently unheard of. The technique, called ‘Sequence-Directed Combinatorial DNA Synthesis” (SDCS) will reduce the costs by three to four orders of magnitude and allow scientists to use computer modeling to optimize gene products using basic organisms such as yeast and bacteria.

Mark Annett: Solving the grand unified theory of physics and improving semiconductors (among other things)

Olive Lynch (Green Waste Technologies):  Using black soldier flies & composting to address the growing issue of food waste. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Panelists

John Frankel is the founding partner of ff Venture Capital, an early-stage venture capital firm and has been an early-stage investor since late 1999. John was one of the earliest investors in Quigo Technologies, which was purchased by AOL in December 2007. John currently serves on the boards of 500px, Adcade, Appy Couple, Bottlenose, Cardflight, ClearPath Immigration, CoPromote, Distil Networks, Estify, InteraXon, Milkster, Moveline, Mulu, Phone.com, Tackk, Unikey, and VolunteerSpot.

Susan Okin Goldsmith is a partner in the law firm McCarter & English, LLP, where she is a member of the intellectual property and information technology practice group.  Susan handles a wide variety of matters involving technology licensing, trademark registration strategy and licensing, copyrights, e-commerce and internet use and abuse, and issues involving international trade.

Troy Hollar is the COO of Merlin Organics, and an entrepreneur who has over 20 years of diverse experience in producing media and entertainment, building brands, and developing technology. His work in such diverse fields as marketing and advertising, web development, film production, and theater have enabled him to work with enterprises and organizations as varied as Fortune 100 companies, world-class stage and film producers, and award-winning artists.

Dennis Bone.  Everyone from the North Jersey entrepreneurial scene knows Dennis Bone.  He's that guy.  Dennis was previously President of Verizon NJ for 12+ years and is currently the Director of the Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship at Montclair State University.  

2) What's your [x]? + What's your moonshot?

The incomparable Jay Treble will be on hand doing his normal videography magic.  This means that sessions will be recorded and we'll also be live-streaming the event at <a>www.nj.org.</a> 

What this also means is that we'd love to see people bring along their own 30-second "What's your moonshot?" elevator pitch to present to the camera before the main event kicks off at 6:30.  You can come with a moonshot that solves a big problem in the world, or an [x] that points out a big problem in the world that needs a solution.  

We also encourage you to find Linda and take a "What's your X?" photo such as this one (hopefully with a straighter left arm).   Then help us start a viral campaign by posting the photo along with your stated [x] all over social media using the hashtags: #whatsyourx and #solveforxnj

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Solve for X: New Jersey

This is the first qualifying event of GDG North Jersey's Solve for X (SFX) campaign. What is Solve for X you may ask? SFX is a global initiative from Google [x] which aims to find pioneers in science and technology who are working on huge game changing “moonshots” and accelerating their progress to impact the world in positive ways.

GDG North Jersey was selected as 1 of 12 sites in the world and 1 of only 2 in the USA to host an SFX as part of Google's first ever series of partner led events. At this event we will hear from some of the brightest minds in the region as they present their breakthrough solutions to huge problems in the world.

This event is open to anyone who would like to attend.  Applications to present a moonshot at this event are open until Dec 1st.  Follow the link below and click on "Submit Your Moonshot" to submit your concept and be considered for inclusion in the lineup.

name: Solve for X: Google NYC
description:
Agenda

5:15 - 6:00: Register 

6:00: Registration closes

5:30 - 6:15: Food, networking, What's your [x]?

6:20 - 6:40: Welcome / Opening Remarks

6:40+: Moonshot pioneer pitches along with feedback from an esteemed panel.  The core team is very excited about the talent that has been building for this event. 

8:30: Closing remarks

"After the party, there's the after party."

----------------------------------------------------------------

Moonshot Pioneers

Leonard Flom (Ophthalmology professor at NYU School of Medicine):  He may have an ultraviolet photon-based cure for Ebola and HIV.    

Norberto Guzman (AffinityCE): Immunoaffinity capillary electrophoresis (IACE) refers to a modular, portable, multi-dimensional point-of-care instrument that combines the technologies of immunoassay and analytical separation.   This device can reduce the cost worldwide for access to expensive medical tests and treatments, and help practitioners obtain rapid and accurate diagnosis and prognosis of diseases.

John Kulp (bioleap): "The Arms Race between Nature’s evolution toolbox and our ability to develop therapies to attack mutating microbes, is not being won. To rapidly produce such therapies, we propose to employ the unprecedented capacity of cloud computing resources to assemble new drugs by linking chemical fragments that are found to bind to critical proteins in ways that avoid mutations. A public repository of chemical fragment maps for 1,000’s of proteins and 100’s of structural variations of such proteins would be made available on the Internet to the broad community of life sciences researchers. Web-based tools would enable them to construct and quantum mechanically evaluate candidate therapies in a highly automated fashion. This capability would vastly accelerate mankind’s ability to respond to the threats of pandemics from drug-resistant 'superbugs'."

Bodo Hoenen (Dev4x): "650 million children will only ever go to the most inadequate of schools, over 50 million will never go to school. We are building an autonomous self-schooling platform that runs on low cost phones and tablets that these children can use to teach themselves anything they need to reach for their dreams."

Rik Riman (Rutgers): His team is working on a reformulated process for concrete.

Wenting Zhang (Stevens Institute of Technology):  “We have developed a new platform for reconstructing patient- specific cancer models (using multiply myeloma as an example) by using microfluidic devices. This new approach allows us to culture hard - to -preserve primary human tumor cells in vitro for personalized drug screening.”

Vincent Ogutu (Rutgers): “I would like to simulate teleportation by enabling people to project 3D holograms of their full body at their intended destination. Their hologram will interact with people at the destination and have the ability to move from one person to another as though they were actually moving in the room.”

-----------------------------------------------------------------

What is Solve for X?

This is the 2nd qualifying event of GDG North Jersey's Solve for X (SFX) campaign. What is Solve for X you may ask? SFX is a global initiative from Google [x] which aims to find pioneers in science and technology who are working on huge game changing “moonshots” and accelerating their progress to impact the world in positive ways.

How are we involved?

GDG North Jersey was selected as 1 of 12 sites in the world and 1 of only 2 in the USA to host an SFX as part of Google's first ever series of partner led events. At this event we will hear from some of the brightest minds in the region as they present their breakthrough solutions to huge problems in the world.

This event is open to anyone who would like to attend. Applications to present a moonshot at this event are open until Dec 28th.  Follow the link below and click on "Submit Your Moonshot" to submit your concept and be considered for inclusion in the lineup.

description:
(If you don't get one of the free parking spots (it's limited), we recommend: Garage B 28 2nd Street Hoboken, NJ 07030)

What is Solve for X?

This is the 4th and final qualifying event of GDG North Jersey's Solve for X (SFX) campaign. What is Solve for X you may ask? SFX is a global initiative from Google [x] which aims to find pioneers in science and technology who are working on huge game changing “moonshots” and accelerating their progress to impact the world in positive ways. 

How are we involved?

GDG North Jersey was selected as 1 of 12 sites in the world and 1 of only 2 in the USA to host an SFX as part of Google's first ever series of partner led events. At this event we will hear from some of the brightest minds in the region as they present their breakthrough solutions to huge problems in the world.

This event is open to anyone who would like to attend.  Applications to present a moonshot at this event are open until Jan 7th.  Follow the link below and click on "Submit Your Moonshot" to submit your concept and be considered for inclusion in the lineup.

http://solveforx.gdgnorthjersey.com/ 

Agenda:

5:45 - 6:15: Register 

5:45 - 6:15: Networking, What's your [x]?, Android Wear & GA Hub booths

6:20 - 6:40: Welcome / Opening Remarks

6:40+: Moonshot pioneer pitches along with feedback from an esteemed panel.  Details below. 

8:30: Closing remarks

"After the party, there's the after party."

Moonshot Pioneers:

Gedi Mainelis (Rutgers University): Gedi will present "A novel device to substantially improve our ability to capture particle pollutants from diesel exhaust. This technology offers great advantages over existing methods to capture diesel exhaust particles. Preliminary testing shows ability to capture more than 95% of diesel exhaust particles."

Karlin Yeh (Cooper Union): "The standard method to counter beach erosion is to dredge sand from an offshore site and transport it to the eroding beach, often costing upwards of $8 million for a mere 1,500 linear feet of beach. This method destroys marine ecosystems and is extremely inefficient because it must be repeated every few years. Instead, we propose to use wave pumps, similar to the CETO wave pump, which would constantly pump a slurry mix back to the beach that would then be deposited by the incoming tide. Compared to the dredging method, the wave pumps would, in theory, be able to replenish the beach more effectively and be less disruptive compared to the current dredging method." 

Mark Punyanitya (MagnePath):  MagnePath is a company that joins us all the way from Australia.  They are developing "body mapping applications to provide the ultimate 'quantified self'. Our mission is to improve quality of life, by making personalized health information more accessible, actionable, and meaningful. Our Moonshot is to create an individualized picture of health, by measuring all of the organs and tissues in a person's body, for presentation as a platform for biometric signals, laboratory data, and medical information."

Steven Saldana (XLabsCorp): "At the core of our revolutionary data compression technology is Artificial Intelligence. Synapse, our living artificial consciousness, created the world's most sophisticated data compression algorithm.  We are producing a 99.92% lossless compression rate. There is no one even close."

Marianna Zaslavsky (FlexTraPower): "Our Moonshot is to create a low-cost version of the sensing component that can be integrated onto a small bandaid-like product and distributed to entire populations by global health organizations (WHO, Red Cross) and governments during times of epidemics and outbreaks. An entire population’s temperature can be transmitted wirelessly to the cloud in real-time at incredibly accurate and fast rates, allowing for these global health organizations and governments to understand both real-time and historical body temperature data for better monitoring, faster prevention and faster treatment."

James Finkle (NJ Transit Board): "A dedicated 'fast lane' on major highways which surrenders the control of the car to the highway via ECM. Once entered into the 'fast lane' the cars controls would be surrendered to the highway controls via the ECM. The driver would need to provide feedback in order to exit the fast lane and could preprogram a departure spot."

Panelists:

Werner Kuhr is the Director of Technology Commercialization and Industry Professor of Chemistry at Stevens Institute. There, he leads the continuing development of the university's intellectual property portfolio and plays a significant role in implementing the innovation and entrepreneurship components of the university’s strategic plan.

Aaron Price is the founder of NJ Tech Meetup, New Jersey's largest technology and entrepreneurship focused Meetup group.  He's also the cofounder and CEO of livecube, whose flagship product is an app that amplifies audience engagement at events by applying game mechanics to every attendee interaction.

Dr. Poonam Alaigh is CEO and President of Alaigh Care Associates LLC, a national healthcare consulting company leading in the implementation of healthcare reform and is a member of the Board of Directors of The Common Sense Institute of New Jersey - a nonpartisan think tank that conducts scholarly research and analysis of New Jersey public policy.  

Dr. Poonam served on Gov. Chris Christie's cabinet as Commissioner of Health and Senior Services for New Jersey where she was had responsibility for direct operational oversight and management of the Department of Health and Senior Services with a budget of $3.8B, and 1700 employees.

David J. Shulkin, M.D. is President at Morristown Medical Center, President of Atlantic Accountable Care Organization and Vice President of Atlantic Health System.  Dr. Shulkin has been named as one of the Top 100 Physician Leaders of  Hospitals and Health Systems by Becker’s Hospital Review and one of the “50 Most Influential Physician Executives in the Country” by Modern Healthcare and Modern Physician.   He has also been named,   “One Hundred Most Influential People in American Healthcare” by Modern Healthcare.

Lesson 1: Create Project Sunshine

What is Android Study Jam?

Android Study Jam is a free, GDG-facilitated 8 week course developed by Udacity & Google for people who would like to learn Android Development to build mobile apps. 

Participants must be registered with Udacity by navigating to the following URL and clicking on "Sign Up":  

Click here to officially register for the course

The study group will run for 8 weeks on a set schedule: once a week (every Thursday) for 7 weeks, followed by an 8th meeting for sharing final projects. 

Participants will attend review sessions and commit to completing the online lessons each week. The study jam will be led by a certified Android facilitator who administers each session and is able to offer guidance and tutor students from all different skill levels, including beginners.

Benefits for students:

• Free in-person tutoring & course assistance

• Support community of other students

• Opportunity to get final projects evaluated for course certificate and credit toward larger “nano-degree”

• Swag & prize opportunities

More about Google Developer Groups study jams here:

name: Women Innovation 2015 Summit: Business, Politics & Innovation
description:
Men and women, come join us for a day of collaborative sessions and unique insight into business, politics and innovation as we celebrate International Women's Day on March 8th.

** We've drastically reduced tickets to $10/each thanks to awesome new sponsors and we added the Mayor of South Orange to the lineup! Note that you MUST register for this event on Eventbrite. **

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/women-in-novation-an-international-womens-day-event-tickets-15825911728

International Women's Day celebrates the social, political and economic achievements of women. This event is a joint collaboration between Women Techmakers North Jersey, Propel Media Group, PowerPatterns, Tara Dowdell Group, =SPACE and Google Developer Group: GDG North Jersey.

Admission gives you access to all activities including workshops, keynotes, food and refreshments.

Keynote Speakers

Sarah Miller Caldicott - Founder, PowerPatterns (www.powerpatterns.com) "The Role of Ingenuity and Work Culture in Innovation: Creating a Shared Ecosystem"

Sarah is a great grandniece of Thomas Edison, an innovation thought leader, and CEO of her own Chicago-based innovation consultancy, The Power Patterns of Innovation. An innovative expert, she has written two books entitled 'Innovate Like Edison' and 'Midnight Lunch'. Sarah's work has appeared in the New York Times, Fast Company, USA Today, TEDx, and Fortune as well as on CNBC and PBS.

Tara Dowdell - Founder, Tara Dowdell Group (www.taradowdellgroup.com) "Growing Your Startup: The Business of Innovation & Entrepreneurship"

Tara is a highly accomplished business and political strategist. She is the Founder and President of Tara Dowdell Group, a marketing and strategic consulting firm focused on helping socially conscious businesses, organizations and brands grow. Tara Dowdell Group has cultivated an impressive list of clients in healthcare, education, transportation infrastructure, real estate development and government.

In addition to her consulting practice, Tara is a respected television commentator and speaker. She appears regularly on MSNBC and Al Jazeera America where she provides progressive insight and analysis on a range of political, government and business topics. She can also be seen on Fox 5 Good Day New York and Fox 5 News at 6:00 p.m.

Alex Torpey - Mayor, South Orange

Alex was elected as Mayor of South Orange at the ripe old age of 23.  At the time of being sworn in (May 16, 2011), he was the youngest Village President in South Orange’s history, and the youngest serving mayor in the state of New Jersey. 

He believes in doing government differently. He believes in a government that excites, innovates and inspires. He will join us for a quick talk and also discuss some challenges facing his town and call upon attendees to help solve these problems.

Agenda

12:30 – 1:00 Registration, Networking & 'Office Hours'

1:00 – 1:15 Opening remarks by Women Techmakers, Propel Media Group and =SPACE

1:15 – 1:45 Sarah Caldicott "The Role of Ingenuity and Work Culture in Innovation: Creating a Shared Ecosystem"

1:45 – 2:00 Interactive discussions

2:00 – 2:20 Tara Dowdell - Keynote

2:20 – 2:45 Hors d'oeuvres served

2:45 – 3:15 Collaborative workshop: Navigating corporate & start-up ecosystems in the digital age

3:15 – 3:45 Workshop group feedback

3:45 – 4:30 Panel Discussion: My Journey, My Learnings - featuring Sarah Caldicott, Tara Dowdell, Tai Cooper & Talia Young

4:30 – 4:45 Closing remarks

4:45 - 5:00 Networking

5:00+ After party at Hotel Indigo


Additional Featured Speakers "Panel Discussion: My Journey, My Learnings"

Tai Cooper, Chief Policy Advisor at City of Newark

Talia Young, Assistant Vice President of Public and Government Relations at City National Bank

Medina, Creative Director at =SPACE

For more info, check out the dedicated website at:

http://iwd.gdgnorthjersey.com/womeninnovation

Also make sure to help us get the conversation started at #IWDNJ. Top tweets and G+ posts will be rewarded at the event itself!

Christina "CK" Kerley (allthingsck.com) will speak about The Smart Revolution: How The “Internet of Things” Will Shape Our Lives, Our Work—And Our World

A forerunner in tech revolutions for 20 years, innovation speaker and specialist Christina “CK” Kerley steers executives through the sweeping set of emerging tech and trends that are transforming our world today… and those igniting the strategies, brands and business models of tomorrow.

Lucy He of Google

She'll help us kick the tires on Google's Polymer, a next generation web development framework. Lucy will conduct a hands-on Code Lab, where attendees will have the opportunity to build their own Polymer "element".

Lucy is a software engineer in Social Impact at Google. As a front-end developer, her goal is to help bring the best user experiences to life. She likes Polymer, simplicity and thoughtful design. +1 for good code and code for good!

Laptop with Python, Node.js (which includes npm) and Bower installed. (If you're installing for the first time, they should be installed in this order.)

Open JC is a hands on active community group collaborating with the Jersey City Government to build open data, open source and open government in Jersey City. Open JC believes in public sector innovation and the value of digital-government projects.

name: Solve for X: Moonshot Design Sprint at Google NYC
description:
YOU MUST APPLY TO ATTEND
We have partnered with a consortium of Googlers, Ubitech and the NYC EDC to provide you with an opportunity to participate in a unique hands-on design sprint experience to bring moonshot thinking to NYC!

--------------------------------------------------------------

Solving for a Better Future

When: April 25, 2015 | 11:30am - 5pm (lunch provided)

Where: Google NYC (details will be provided for selected participants)

Who: Click to apply now!

Applications accepted until April 15th. Selected participants will be notified by April 18th.

Participation is exclusive and awarded through an application process to our selection committee. We are looking for innovative and curious individuals who are eager to come solve some of NYC’s toughest challenges.

The design sprint will be a half-day iterative brainstorming and prototyping process, adopted from the Google Ventures Design Sprint guidelines.

If you are excited about 10x, audacious thinking in the worlds of science and technology, then you need to join us for this event!

--------------------------------------------------------------

Why is this important?

Currently, there are not enough moonshot projects to meet the challenges facing humanity. And in NYC in particular, we have a lot of difficult challenges that require moonshot thinking to resolve.

What’s a moonshot?

Each Solve for X proposal (what we refer to as a 'tech moonshot') addresses a complex, global problem with a radical solution that makes use of a novel application of existing science or technology, or a game-changing breakthrough.

(Source: https://www.solveforx.com/about)

--------------------------------------------------------------

name: Google Cloud Platform Fundamentals at Google NYC
description:
We've been told that new registrations are now going to waitlist, so we recommend to put yourself on the waitlist, but we can't guarantee that you'll actually get into the event now.  If you're really interested, Google is considering a supplementary event for GDG groups only, if we drum up enough interest.  You can express your interest through the following link: 

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1AbvHkPSGAdUkjNxhUqzVlCsSvveqMT-zeBce66PBF3M/viewform

Google NYC is holding a full day "Google Cloud Platform Fundamentals" training class. It's an 8 hour instructor-led class introducing participants to Google Cloud Platform products and services. Through a combination of instructor-led presentations, demonstrations, and hands-on labs, students learn the value of Google Cloud Platform and how to incorporate cloud-based solutions into business strategies.  

You must register through the following link if you'd like to attend: 

https://goo.gl/qXYC6G

Class Description here:
https://events.withgoogle.com/cp100a-gcp-fundamentals-420068/class-outline/

name: NYC Moonshot Sprint at Grand Central Tech
description:
We have an exciting event to tell you about that's coming up this weekend:

On Saturday, July 25th TeamX in partnership with Google's Solve for X, BigApps, Grand Central Tech, Quirky Inc, Undercurrent and others, are hosting a half-day moonshot sprint. To apply to attend the event, click the following link:

http://apply.moonshot.nyc

The moonshot sprint is geared towards building teams to help solve some of NYC's toughest challenges through moonshot thinking. We're employing a modified Google Venture's design sprint model to form teams to ideate, innovate and prototype around two BigApps challenges: Connected Cities and Zero Waste in NYC. 

Come out to connect and collaborate with other innovators in a dynamic format that encourages 10x thinking within science and technology.

name: Google Cloud Spin Event with Googlers

venue.name: Montclair State University (University Hall - Room UN1070)

description:
We'll be visited by 2 of Google's developer advocates from the Google NYC office. They'll be demoing the "Google Cloud Spin" Android app that they recently built on Google Cloud Platform (GCP). 

Agenda

6:15 pm: Pizza & Networking

6:45 pm: Opening Remarks (Todd Nakamura of GDG North Jersey & Dennis Bone of MSU) 

7:00 pm: "Google Cloud Spin" Ray Tsang & Bret McGowen (Google)

Ray & Bret will walk through features of the Google Cloud Platform used in building the Google Cloud Spin demo shown at recent #GCPNext events. The demo uses an orchestrated set of smartphones to capture multi-angle views of the same event, upload them to the cloud and have them stitched together in real time to create a single 180-degree snapshot of that moment.

Cloud Spin Demo

Come take your own Cloud Spin photo with a live demo that will be setup (along with some Googley props).

Check out the Cloud Spin Twitter account to get an idea of what this all looks like: https://twitter.com/googlecloudspin
how_to_find_us: UN1070 is on the first floor of University Hall at MSU.

name: 1st Annual North Jersey Tech & Entrepreneur Cookout
description:
Here's some help finding the exact location of where we'll be in the park.  Once we're actually there on Sunday, we'll also drop a link in the comments for this event with the exact geo coordinates: 

When in Fort Lee and you are coming from River road, enter the Henry Hudson Drive on your right (red arrows on map below)If you will be coming north from the Hudson Terrace, enter Henry Hudson on your left (purple arrows on map below)

Keep going down Henry Hudson until you arrive at the roundabout. Take the road on your right with the road sign pointing towards the Red Dock Picnic area. Destination is Red Dock Picnic area that will be a few miles ahead.

Those coming from Palisades Parkway, take the Henry Hudson once you enter Fort Lee and drive up to the Red Dock Picnic area (black arrows on map below)

Destination: Once you arrive in the parking lot, our tables will have red & white cloths under two large trees. Directly facing the playground and sligthly away from the river. Also look for the GDG North Jersey sign in case we move tables!!

** If anyone has issues finding us, drop a comment in the event listing.  We'll be monitoring.  (Parking lot available with possible charge of $10 per car. Car pool if possible)

We've been meaning to get the North Jersey tech & entrepreneur scene together for a fun day since last year, and the time is finally coming.  Join us for a relaxed day with food, drinks, merriment, giveaways and some Meetup-y activity at a really cool park on the Hudson. We'll supply a bunch of food and drinks, but we'd love for some people to also bring along some of their favorite dishes (no obligation of course).

Some fun events we're planning: 

1) Startup pitches (If you're a founder and would like to be considered, fill out our Founder's Profile if you haven't previously done so). 

2) Awards for some of our most loyal followers 

3) Ultimate frisbee 

We'll be partnering with a number of other Meetup groups such as LaunchNJ, Scarlet Startups, GNEC and Montclair Entrepreneurs, so opportunities to meet some new people should be in abundance.

name: Self-Driving Car Demo (hosted by NJ's own DriveAI guys)
description:
The DriveAI guys have been working hard on a self-driving vehicle this summer, and they want to share the fruits of their labor with the NJ tech community.  Let's support this awesome work that's happening right in our own backyard! 

TICKETS HANDLED THROUGH EVENTBRITE - GET YOUR FREE TICKET HERE >>>

"Within the last few months you've heard about the self-driving car being developed here in NJ. You've met with some of the DriveAI guys building the vehicle. We've engaged in heated discussions about AI, autonomous vehicles, and the implications of all of this for our future. We understand that the future is simply now. Join DriveAI as we unveil the self-driving vehicle.

At this event, you'll meet the DriveAI team, learn what went into crafting the vehicle, and what's planned further down the road. You'll have a chance to meet many others heavily involved in the autonomous vehicle space. Most importantly, you'll get to see the self-driving car.

Space is limited and registration is required through Eventbrite in order to attend. There are after-hours access restrictions at the venue, so please register at least 12 hours in advance so you're on the list. Come with lots of questions, and prepare to enter the driver's seat!"

name: DevFest 2015: FireHack (Firebase & Google Cloud Platform Hackathon)
description:
VENUE

The event will be held at the Water Tower Cafe within Google NYC. The address is 111 8th Avenue. Please enter by the entrance near 16th Street and 8th Avenue (closer to Citibank). 

We will have registration set up here. Please aim to be here between 8:15 and 8:30am so we can get everyone registered and into the venue before the event kicks off at 8:45am.

** Note that to participate, you must submit the following really short form (1 minute or less to fill out):

bit.ly/gdg-devfest2015-cfp

We're really excited to announce that we've partnered with GDG NYC, GDG Hudson Valley, WeWork and Google to host FireHack.  This is a weekend-long Hackathon at Google New York and WeWork, with a focus on Firebase and Google Cloud Platform as the back-end technologies and your choice of front-end tech.  

Speakers

Martin Omander, Google (Mountain View)

Program Manager for Development Platform

Martin is visiting us from the Google mother ship in Silicon Valley, and is program manager for Google Developer Groups in North America.  He also wears awesome hats.  Martin will welcome us to Google as well as serve as a mentor throughout the event. 

Bret McGowen, Google (NYC) 

Developer Advocate for Firebase and Google Cloud

Bret originally hails from the great state of Texas, and now serves as a Developer Advocate at Google NYC primarily in the areas of Firebase and Google Cloud Platform.  Bret will deliver his awesome "No Stack Development using Firebase" 101 session, which he recently delivered at the NYC Code Camp.  He'll also give a brief intro to Google Cloud Platform, including fundamentals and deployment. 


Elizabeth Padilla, Google (Mountain View) 

Program Manager, Development Platform

Liz works with Martin as a Program Manager for the Developer Platform at Google in Mountain View.  She's an expert in the areas of community development, social media, marketing and public speaking, and will help teams prepare for pitches.  

Jeffrey Posnick, Google (NYC)

Senior Developer Relations Engineer, Open Web Platform

Jeff works as a Dev Relations engineer on the Open Web Platform at Google NYC, and will delivery a quick intro to rapid web development using Polymer. 

For more details about the event, visit the dedicated site: 

http://firehack.splashthat.com/

We'll also have mentors on hand to help you on your projects, as well as free food, prizes for winners and giveaways.  

*Note that because of the large number of groups participating, we will have a limited number of slots for participants. 

For now, please RSVP and get on the wait list for the event if you are interested in attending and if chosen we will reach out to you to confirm your participation.

* Full agenda and themes to come shortly.

name: Android Study Jam (for beginners)

venue.name: Montclair State University: School of Business (Room 101)

description:
Hello GDG Jedi! 

It's Android Study Jam season once again, and we're happy to announce that we've partnered with GDG Newark to kickoff a new series (4-5 weeks) of free courses on Wednesday, Feb. 10th at Montclair State University in the new School of Business building.  

This year's Study Jam (https://www.udacity.com/course/android-development-for-beginners--ud837) is custom-designed for those of you who are looking to break into mobile app development as a beginner, and does not assume any prior development experience.  

The course will be instructed by Ernest Grzybowski, Android Consultant and founding organizer of GDG Newark.  

We'd love to see many of you out there, so come hang out with your local development community and add some new skills to the repertoire.  

Todd 

Course Prerequisites and Requirements 

"If you are new to programming and don’t know where to start, then this is the course for you!

We will use Android Studio to build our apps, so you should have access to a computer that can run Android Studio in order to follow along (see Android Studio’s System Requirements for details). Don’t worry, you do not need to install Android Studio in advance – we will provide detailed installation instructions as part of the course.

Access to an Android device is helpful, but not at all required.

Now, in case you have some programming experience, parts of this course may be too slow for you — you should feel free to skip those sections.

Finally, the most important prerequisite is a willingness to learn new things, and belief that you can do this!

See the Technology Requirements for using Udacity."

Please bring

A computer that satisfies these system requirements

A computer charger

Android device (optional, you can use an Android emulator if needed)

USB cable to connect the device to their computer

Headphones (to watch videos in the classroom)

You DO NOT need to install anything in advance! =)
how_to_find_us: If you're unfamiliar with the campus or the School of Business building, take a look at this campus map.  The building is in the upper left: https://www.montclair.edu/campus-map/

name: Grokking Realm - A New Mobile Database (Hosted by Audible)
description:
Join us for an event that's organized by our friends from GDG Newark. They're running an event entitled "Grokking Realm - A New Mobile Database." They'll be hosted by Audible in their downtown Newark office. The talk will be given by Donn Felker, a Google Developer Expert on Android.

Abstract: Learn about the new mobile database on the block, Realm. With Realm you work with regular Java objects - not SQL, cursors or object mappers. These same Java objects are native to Realm. Learn how to use Realm and its reactive features to build apps faster and more efficiently without having to write a line of SQL. You'll leave with a firm understanding of how to install, setup, store and retrieve data with a Realm database. When you get back to the office you can use Realm to help you focus on solving a business problem instead of worrying about how to get your data in and out of a database.

Pizza and beer will be provided by Audible!

Audible Inc.
1 Washington Place, Newark, NJ, 15th Floor (map)

How to get here:
1. Mass transit

Take Path trains or NJ Transit to Newark Penn Station > Take the Newark Light rail to Washington Park or look for the Audible shuttle outside the main entrance (every 10-20 minutes)

or

Take NJ Transit to Newark Broad Street > walk to 1 Washington Park.

2. Drive

Parking will be free at the main lot. Just say you're here for Audible. Any overflow can park at a paid parking lot close to the building.

name: Intro to Machine Learning: Supervised Learning

venue.name: Montclair State University: School of Business (Room 101)

description:
** Recommended parking is at the Red Hawk Parking Deck. **

If you're looking to learn some of the fundamentals of data science, this is an event that you won't want to miss.

About the Speaker

Manojit Nandi is a Stanford-educated, former Verizon data scientist who currently works at STEALTHBits Technologies focusing on real-time and batch methods for anomaly and threat detection in their enterprise's data.

About the Talk

In this talk, Manojit will be discussing how machine learning is used in data classification tasks. He'll be covering standard machine learning algorithms such as Support Vector Machines and Random Forests, which can be run on any general-purpose computer (no special hardware needed) using Python. 

He'll discuss the behavior of these algorithms from both a quantitative and a qualitative perspective, and how they are used in applied settings. This talk is designed for people who have no background in machine learning, so no prior knowledge of statistics or machine learning is assumed. 

Feel free to bring your own laptop if you'd like to follow along with the talk/demo.

name: Docker Orchestration and Multi-Cloud Management with Saltstack

venue.name: Montclair State University: School of Business (Room 101)

description:
If you're driving in, we recommend parking at the Red Hawk Parking Deck.

We'll be joined by Dave Giles and Frank Casper of Saltstack (www.saltstack.com), a major player in the area of cloud orchestration and automation. 

Dave, an engineer at Salt will provide an introduction to the Salt Project. Specifically, Salt's background, components and architecture, along with a demo use case of building an NGINX farm in docker containers behind a HAProxy instance. 

Additionally,  Dave will also use Salt to spin up, configure and execute commands across multiple clouds to demo Salt's cloud abstraction layer.
how_to_find_us: Second Floor (Main conference room) of the School of Business (Park at Red Hawk parking deck)

name: Machine Learning, Security and Harry Potter??  (with a Googler)

venue.name: Montclair State University: School of Business (Room 114)

description:
In this exciting talk straight out of Hogwart's Academy, Yufeng Guo of the Google Cloud team at Google New York will present for the very first time, the aptly titled: "Harry Potter dorm doors -- A wizarding approach to security". 

Description

The entranceways to the dorms at Hogwarts were guarded by paintings that talked and asked for passwords. What if that were real?! The recent availability of machine learning as a cloud API opens up the door to an exponential growth in the possibilities for 'smart' devices. In this talk, we explore a Harry Potter style 'security' system that can both see and hear.

About Yufeng 

Yufeng Guo is a Developer Programs Engineer, working at Google New York.  He's an expert in the areas of cloud technology and machine learning, and is often found speaking at various tech events in the NJ/NY area.  He's also an avid runner, and all around awesome guy.

name: Hackathon: Google Cloud Machine Learning at Rutgers Newark
description:
Hello GDG Jedi! 

We're excited to announce that we've teamed up with The Ideas Maker and Rutgers Newark this year to host a 2-day Hackathon at Rutgers Newark based on the recently released Google Cloud Machine Learning API.  

Event Agenda

DAY 1  (Oct 22) 

10:00 am   Registration / Coffee & Snacks Served

10:45 am    Welcome from Organizers

11:00 am    Google Cloud Vision API 101 (Todd Nakamura)

11:15 am      Google Cloud Voice API & Prototype Demo (Rahul Anand & TIM Team)

11:30 am    Event Logistics (Schedule of Events | Team Formation Kickoff)

12:00 am   Coffee Break & Networking

12:30 pm   Let the Hacking Commence!

12:30 pm   Lunch Served (Costco Sandwiches)

2:00 pm   Teams Register on Slack

3:30 pm   Coffee Served

6:30 pm   Day Session Wrap Up

DAY 2 

10:00 am   Doors Open / Coffee & Snacks Served 

10:00 am   Hacking Continues

12:00 pm   Lunch Served (Pizza)

1:30 pm   Ensure that All Pitching Teams are Noted (Slack)

2:00 pm   Teams Practice Pitches with Mentors

2:30 pm   Judge Intros

2:45 pm   Hack Presentations

4:00 pm Judges Feedback & Audience Favorite Vote

4:30 pm Prizes Awarded, Raffle Winners & Closing Statements

What You'll Learn

The exciting new framework provides access to features such as: 

1) The Cloud Vision API, which enables developers to programmatically analyze the contents of an image by leveraging powerful machine learning models through a simple REST API.  "It quickly classifies images into thousands of categories (e.g. "sailboat", "Eiffel Tower"), detects individual objects and faces within images, and finds and reads printed words contained within images."  

2) The Cloud Speech API, which "enables you to convert audio to text by applying neural network models in an easy to use API. The API recognizes over 80 languages and variants, to support your global user base. You can transcribe the text of users dictating to an application’s microphone or enable command-and-control through voice among many other use cases."

What to Expect

So come out, connect with other developers in the community, and learn about an exciting new world of programming power that has been put at our fingertips.  We'll have food, prizes for winning teams, and plenty of talented mentors and speakers to get you started on the machine learning cloud platform.

Our Speakers

Alfred Blake

</a>

<a href="http://www.rulebreakeru.com/">

</a><a href="http://www.rulebreakeru.com/">www.rulebreakeru.com
Alfred is the assistant director of the Entrepreneurship Programs Rutgers Business School & Founder of Rule Breaker University. A successful business man, he additionally mentors and coaches entrepreneurship to over 500 students in the Newark and New Brunswick campuses of Rutgers Business School.

Todd Nakamura

Todd is the founder of Google Developers Group North Jersey and a full-time software and database architect.  

Kristina Durante

www.kristinadurante.com
Kristina Durante is an associate professor of marketing and the marketing PhD program coordinator at Rutgers Business School. Kristina is a social psychologist interested in the biology of decision-making.

Richard Berta

Richard is the DoubleClick Agency Lead at Google. His motto in three words: "Simplify, Amplify, Optimize." He is a Googler who's accumulated ten years of experience across digital & social marketing, including: programmatic media, marketing automation, management consulting and media sales.

Rafael Soberal

Rafael is an award-winning creative director with a strong business sensibility leads multi-country teams to develop and reposition brands across the US, Asia, Europe, and Latin America through strategic integration of digital, social, and traditional solutions. His clients include the likes of Disney! 

Cheryl McCants

Cheryl McCants is a bilingual, award-winning communications professional and entrepreneur with 25+ years of experience. She is the president and CEO of Impact Consulting Enterprises, a New Jersey-based strategic communication, marketing and public relations firm with global reach.

Manojit Nandi

Manojit Nandi is a data scientist who has worked in cyber-security and marketing analytics. He specializes in statistical machine learning and is interested in how to use data to solve problems with high social impact.

Rahul Anand

Rahul Anand is the founder and general partner at The Ideas Maker, a web and app development company which he founded while persuing his degree at Rutgers. He is also the Rutgers Student Entrepreneur of the Year and an ex-google employee. You can read more about him here.

name: Getting Familiar With: Android RecyclerView
description:
"Getting Familiar With" is a series provided by GDG North Jersey that will take place online. This series is focused on providing real-world experience that you can take into your next project, portfolio, or job. Each topic will include a variety of videos, articles, and challenges to review and complete to become familiar with the topic at hand. You will be invited to join a Slack group where you'll be able to discuss any issues you run into. The start date is the kick off of the subject at hand, and we will be working and communicating in the chat throughout the month.

This months topic is the Android RecyclerView. The RecyclerView is one of the most important components in Android as it allows you to efficiently layout long lists of data in a performant manner. 

Please RSVP and complete the form here:

https://goo.gl/forms/ZLRS3qnQPpfeDVKB2

name: Flutter Study Jam 2018
description:
The Flutter Study Jams are Community-run study groups based on the Flutter Udacity Course. Participants learn how to use Flutter to develop high-quality, interactive mobile applications for iOS and Android devices.

This event will be kicked off on Saturday August, 4th. Please make sure that your email on meetup.com is correct as that is where you will receive further instructions.

name: DevFest Holidays Extravaganza
description:
Let's get together for another, big event of the year - DevFest. We will have talks, we will have codelabs and actual demos. Topics we will cover - ML/AI, Cloud, Android, Web, Augmented Reality. We will also celebrate holidays, so we can have fun while we learn.

RSVP Here: https://devfestholidayparty.splashthat.com/

Join our slack channel at https://join.slack.com/t/gdg-nb/shared_invite/enQtNDgxNDU1NDM2NjU3LTc3ZDNmNDg0ZDNkNjdiOWI2YTlkZGZkZGJkYzM2MjhkZWY3Njc3MmUyNDI3ODRjMWQ3M2FkNzNkNTg0ODY3MmU

Agenda (Still taking shape. Will definitely change a little bit):
11:00AM - Welcome and Networking. Wear your ethnic best for a chance to win a Google Home Mini.
11:20AM - Talk-1 (Google Cloud)
11:40AM - Talk-2 (Web)
12:00PM - Talk-3 (Mobile)
12:20PM - Feast n Play (There will be prizes - 4 Google Chromecasts to be won)
1:00PM - Track 1: Sessions and CodeLabs on Qwiklabs (Chance to win 3 Google Home mini(s) for completing full 'quests' within a week)
1:00PM - Track 2: ARCore Workshop (Chance to win a Daydream VR headset. Complete this workshop, i.e. having the completed app deployed on an android phone)
1:00PM - Track 3: Mini-Hackathon - Topics would include Material Design, Mobile Apps (Mobile Web included), AI for Social Good, Vision 2030. Team with the best idea will win a "Google HomeHub". Join our Slack Channel for more details, including judging criteria, presentation templates, etc..
4:00PM - Selection of winners and prize giveaways. Concluding remarks, 4:15PM - [Optional] Head over to nearby bar for after-party! Also on-the-house.

name: Android Developer Fundamentals Course
description:
Android Developer Fundamentals

Please make sure to join the GDG North Jersey Slack here: https://join.slack.com/t/gdgnorthjersey/shared_invite/enQtNTMzMjI1NTY0MjA5LTU0MzUwNGNiOTA3Njg3MjViZmVjNWMwOTA0MTc0ZjJjYjUyN2RjNjMzNzZjOGUzOWZhZTI0OWE2NjQ3ZjJhNGE

and then join the #android-course channel

Looking to break into Android development? This course is for you!

"In the Android Developer Fundamentals training, you learn basic Android programming concepts and build a variety of apps, starting with Hello World and working your way up to apps that schedule jobs, update settings, and use Android Architecture Components."

How will it work?
1. Kickoff the course with a Google Video Hangout (link will be shared on Slack)
2. Continue working on codelabs at your own pace over the span of a few weeks
3. Weekly Google Video Hangouts with an Android developer so you can feel free to ask any questions that come to mind

name: hash code - Team up and Prepare for Online Qualification Round
description:
We're teaming up with GDG New Brunswick for this event!

Check out their meetup page here: https://www.meetup.com/gdg-nb/events/258565140/

We will meet and form teams for Hash Code 2019 - Online Qualification Round!

You can find out more about the competition, and register yourself as a participant here: http://g.co/hashcode

Registration form also has an option to let Google Recruiters know if you are interested in working for Google. So, this competition could be your gateway into Google.

Hash Code is divided into 2 stages:

Thursday, February 28th from 17:30 to 21:30 UTC: Online Qualification Round

Saturday, April 27th: Final Round for top teams at Google Ireland

Let's get ready for Hash Code 2019!

Chance to get a glimpse into software engineering at Google during Hash Code, a team programming competition that tasks developers with solving a Google engineering problem.

In past years, teams have tackled challenges such as routing self-driving cars through a simulated city and optimizing the layout of a Google data center.

******
